Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2007 05:58PM sherryw wrote: Annie My port surgery was so easy.  Will they be putting you to sleep to have it done?  I was put to sleep and when I woke up very little pain.  Went home within 45 minutes of waking up from the surgery. I felt fine.  I just had mine out about a month ago, I asked surgeon to put me to sleep as I am a big baby with needles, he said I could if I really wanted him to but that it wasn't bad getting a local numbing medicine.  So that is what he did and it was a breeze, I barely felt the numbing medicine.  What bothered me the most was the itching as it healed.   You will do just fine. sherry

Posts.Title: Port Question AO44 Areyousure

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2009 09:57PM sherryw wrote: Karma, I agree with the other girls on your sisters treatment, first is, that if you feel that you should get a second opinion then you should definitely do so.  I had almost the same treatment that the doctor wants to give to your sister except that I did not get a mastectomy, I had a lumpectomy, my surgeon got real clear margins the first time on the lumpectomy, and my lump was only 2cm, so my surgeon was comfortable just to do the breast conserving surgery and we agreed.   As far as the Chemo treatment I do not feel that your doctor is being to aggressive, it is the exact chemo regimen that I had.  I was 40 when I was diagnosed and with your sister being 31 the doctors wants to hit it good because of her age, she is young.  Also your sister had 17 positive lymph-nodes,  (I am sorry to say this but I am sure you came here for honest answers to your questions) but that is a lot of nodes to be positive, so I would let the doctor knock this beast out of her with all he has to offer. I would not worry to much about the heart issues they are usually a problem for older women, also they watch and monitor your heart.   Chemo is tough but it is doable, many of the girls here are able to continue to work while going through treatments, and remember breast cancer is no longer an automatic death sentence.  She will do just fine, and the fact that she is young will help her get through this easier.  Also, you sound like a loving sister, so gather your resources and friends and set up a schedule for meals to be brought in to her and her family the few days after her treatments.  People want to help maybe drive her kids (if she has them) to school or clean her house things like that will really help her.   The Adriamycin is the first one they will do and it is the one that made me really sick the few days following the infusion, but they have really good anti-nausea drugs for that.  It is also the one that will take her hair about 14 days or so after the first infusion.  The next will be the Taxol it never really made me sick just weak and it can give you neuropathy in your fingers and toes.  And the the Herceptin that is a really good drug that is saving so many lives, I had it once a week for 1 year, you just go to the oncologist and get an IV drip for about an hour and then after a few treatments they will cut that time down to 1/2 hour a week.  That one is really doable and that is the one that they really monitor your heart function.  But not many bad side affects to that one for most people.  And the radiation was very easy for me, it just made me really tired and a little sore.   They will probably want to give your sister a port, it is an easy surgery.  But a port will save her veins and it makes the infusions pretty painless as far as needles. This is something you and your sister will be looking back on in years to come and realizing that it made you closer.   Just try to cry with her when you need to and laugh when you can and have fun when you can.  Hope this helps Sherry
Posts.Title: Too long and aggresive? Need advice Karma76 apple

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2007 06:37PM sherryw wrote: Areyousure You will be able to figure out your stage by your pathology report.  Stage depends on size of tumor, if there are any lymph-nodes involved, and if cancer has moved beyond the nodes.  There is a staging section on the information portion of this board, just go to the very top of this page and type in stages in the search and it should get you there. Do you have any of your pathology results yet? sherry
Posts.Title: Port Question AO44 Areyousure

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2007 07:51PM sherryw wrote: Areyouthere I copied this from this site, by what you have said it looks to me like you are stage II.    Stage I This stage describes invasive breast cancer (cancer cells are breaking through to or invading neighboring normal tissue) in which Stage II This stage describes invasive breast cancer in which: Stage III Stage III is divided into subcategories known as IIIA and IIIB. Stage IIIA Stage IIIA describes invasive breast cancer in which: Stage IIIB This stage describes invasive breast cancer in which a tumor of any size has spread to the breast skin, chest wall, or internal mammary lymph nodes (located beneath the breast right under the ribs, inside the middle of the chest). Stage IIIB includes inflammatory breast cancer, a very uncommon but very serious, aggressive type of breast cancer. The most distinguishing feature of inflammatory breast cancer is redness involving part or all of the breast. The redness feels warm. You may see puffiness of the breast's skin that looks like the peel of a navel orange ("peau d'orange"), or even ridges, welts, or hives. And part or all of the breast may be enlarged and hard. A lump is present only half of the time. Inflammatory breast cancer is sometimes misdiagnosed as a simple infection. sherry

Thanks so much for you support. For you girls that just had the SRS procedure I am glad things went well and that it was not to uncomfortable.  I hope that is the only time you have to do that. Posts.Content: May 22, 2010 08:50PM - edited May 22, 2010 09:09PM by sherryw I had an MRI today due to headache's in my temples.  I have had these headaches for about 8 weeks now.  I asked to be put on antibiotics about 4 weeks ago,  last time I had headaches it ended up being a sinus infection.  The CT scan revealed mucus deposits in my sinuses, so after they put me on antibiotics the headaches went away after a few days.  But this time the antibiotics didn't take the headaches away. So my oncologist order an MRI... UGH.... I am extremely claustrophobic,  I have not cried in months and today I cried when they put me in the machine.  They had to pull me back out.  They allowed my husband to come in the MRI room to help me, but that didn't even work.  I took a xanax before I went to the hospital just not in time for it to take affect.  I had to have them put a rag on my eyes, that helped.  I think I would have been a little better had they not taped my head down, and they put this cage thing on my head.  UGH...But about 10 minutes into the MRI the xanax took affect and I was much calmer. I read you girls talking about HER 2 + having an increased risk of brain mets,  I had never heard that before, is that from new research?  I also had slurred speech about 2 months ago,  but didn't really think it might be something with my brain until now.  I am also worried that maybe I may have had a small stroke ( listen to me thinking  of the worst).  I just chalked the slurred speech to side effects from my meds. I guess I will find out in a few days.    Thanks girls I am sorry I just read this part of the forum is for stage IV,  should I delete this and post somewhere else.

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2007 08:44PM - edited Dec 16, 2007 08:49PM by sherryw I was in a clinical trial for herceptin. My insurance company nor myself had to pay for any of the 52 herceptin treatments I got. There were a total of 5000 bc patients that were treated free of charge because of being in this trial.  Yes, they were to some degree using us as guinea pigs, but I am grateful for what they gave me as we pay for our own health insurance ($800.00) a month.  If the cost of the herceptin and other care I got while on the trial would have went on our insurance it would have cost my insurance company an additional $100,000 which I know would have put the cost of our insurance way out of our reach.  So, I am grateful for whoever paid for it, maybe the drug company maybe donations I'm not sure but I am sure glad it was made possible for me and the 4,999 others. One thing you can be sure of is that the people that own the drug companies and the people that do the research and also the doctors who treat us also have grandmothers, mothers, wives, daughters and even males in their families that have been touched by this horrible monster.  So I am sure they would love to find a cure for this horrible disease if they could. If this horrible disease ends up taking my life I will be happy knowing that there are many who have been cured by the research that has been done.

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2008 07:51PM sherryw wrote: BlueWillow I had the runny nose when I was on the Taxol,  I didn't try any meds like and anti-histamine or anything like that but it may help. Also for the watery eyes.  Watery eyes means that your eyes are dry, yep I said watery eyes are dry, my onc had me use drops for dry eyes like Refresh and Systane.  So you may give those a try. It worked for me. BlueWillow  I noticed you are Her+  have you started Herceptin yet? I was on Herceptin weekly for a year, and the side affect I had from that was, diarrhea all the time.  I had to take 8 benefiber tablets a day to get a normal BM. I took 2 in morning, 2lunch  2 supper, 2 bedtime.   I hope this info helps sherry

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2009 06:29PM sherryw wrote: Jackie, I have had a number of surgery's on my stomach area and the best way to get rid of the gas pains is to MOVE, MOVE, MOVE because the gas is not in your stomach or your digestive system, it is in your stomach cavity.  When they do surgery laproscopically they fill you belly with air and it is that air that your body is trying to get rid of, so really the best way to relieve it is to move, even though it hurts try as hard as you can to keep moving.  I hope goes fine with your recovery.

Posts.Title: Can you please tell.. flower123 crazydaisy

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2008 03:11PM sherryw wrote: Flower The Axillary node dissection is when they take out some of your lymph nodes from under your arm to test them to see if the cancer has spread to the lymph nodes.  Mostly now they do a SNB( sentinel node biopsy) which is where they just shoot some dye into you and see if the nodes are cancerous it is less invasive.  I did not qualify for the SNB because I had a real big lymph node that could be felt.  A sister of my friend just had the surgery you are going to have and hers ended up being calcification's.  She is healing just fine with no problems just a little sore, she is just so happy that it wasn't cancer. Did you have any biopsies at all?  sherry
Posts.Title: Can you please tell.. flower123 crazydaisy

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2008 08:51PM sherryw wrote: Kathleen I didn't have the same combination as you but I did have Adriamycin and Cytoxan and then Taxol.  You mentioned heartburn, I also had heartburn it was really bad, one of the reasons is that the chemo kills fast growing cells and those are the type of cells that are in your digestive system.  That is part of the reason that you get nauseated also.  My oncologist gave me previcid twice a day and it helped some.  I got sick about 8 hours after I got my chemo infusion.  Just remember your oncologist wants to know if you are sick because as my oncologist said, " I have an arsenal of medicine we can try until we find something that works to take your nausea away or at least lesson it."  So make sure you let them know what is going on don't suffer if you don't have too.  Some go through chemo without any problems while others have many problems we are all different. Hope this helps sherry
Posts.Title: question about chemo bean4865 Laura-Vic

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2009 03:11PM sherryw wrote: Linda, It sounds like you found it early and that is the best.  It also is fairly small.  My cancer was 2 cm and I had 3 positive lymph-nodes.  You may not even need chemo, if they get clear margins when they go in to take it out and if there are no lymph-nodes involved, then you may not need much treatment.  You'll get a lot of information on the 4th remember to always get a copy of your pathology reports when you go to doctors office, they will kindly give them to you.  That way when you come here with questions we will be able to help you so much better if we know exactly what type of tumor it is like grade, er or pr positive or neg also if it is her2 positive or neg all of these impact the type of treatment they will be able to offer you.  It will help you make decisions.   I suggest at the top right hand side of this page right under where it says e-mail to a friend notice it says Add to my favorite topics, if you click that button then you will get an e-mail when someone replies to your post.  It makes it much easier you don't have to go around looking on the board for your post, just a suggestion. Hang in there like the others said the waiting is the hardest part but you will get though it. Sorry you had to find us because of the BC beast, but glad you did, there is so much support on this site. sherry

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2008 08:38PM sherryw wrote: Mable Also if your colonoscopy was done in the hospital you can go to the hospital a few days after your colonoscopy and go to medical records and ask for copies of your test results, they have to give them to you.  I have done this several times after my tests because the results are usually read and documented within a few days, but you usually have to wait for a doctors appointment so your dr can give you the results.  Just don't tell the record people that you haven't got the results from you doctor yet, tell them that you need them because you keep a copy of everything.  I feel I am better prepared for my doctor visit when I have the results digested before i go. sherry

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2009 01:15AM sherryw wrote: DX at 40     I always did my monthly exams,  Did one in Dec 04 no lump.  Then I had a bad shoulder and had to use my other hand to help roll myself over in bed and when I did that i felt the lump clear my right side of my breast almost under my arm.,  That was Feb 05 went to doctor the next morning and found out I had BC.  So my tumor grew fast, it was not there in December but it was 2 cm in Feb.  Going to get a small lump out March 20th and get it sent for a biopsy to check on it but we think it is scar tissue ,  But it will look better to me in a jar.

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2008 04:28PM sherryw wrote: Chisame The MRI should pick up any chest mets,  so you will know soon. I had chest pressure for about 7-8 months, the doctors thought it was my heart, I was even on heart meds at 42 years old,( I do not have mets) my chest pressure ended up being, a esophagus condition called Barretts esophagus.  I started on daily Nexium and the chest pain disappeared within a few days and I went off the heart meds.  So you may ask your doctor for a gastro medicine.  I think it's worth a try.  Also you could ask for a nerve medicine such as Xanax or Valuim and take it when you feel that way and if it goes away it must have been anxiety.  I think you might need to go through the process of elimination.  Hang in there sherry

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2009 10:11PM sherryw wrote: Angie, I definitely get it checked out, however most Breast Cancer is not painful..  Most of us did not have any pain.  But, there are some that have, but as a general rule there is no pain.  If you are having pain under your arm it could be that your body is trying to fight something off and your lymph nodes are working.  So try not to get to worried but definitely get it checked out and don't let the doctors blow you off.  If you have not had a mammogram yet, then you should have a baseline mammogram since your mother has had breast cancer.  My doctor told me that my daughter should get her first mammogram 10 years before the age I was diagnosed.  So since I was diagnosed at 40 my daughter should have her first mammo at 30.  I hope all this helps.  Try not to worry if you don't have to.  I know it is hard but Thursday will be here before you know it. Hang in there Sherry

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2008 05:30PM sherryw wrote: Andrea I think if you would call around to some of the beauty shops in your area, you might be able to find a sympathetic hair dresser to do your new do for free.  I really don't think you will have to call around to much before you find a kind soul to do this for you.  Also, you could ask at your oncologist office to see if there is a Look Good, Feel Good, class in your area.  It is a class that helps you learn how to put on make-up and how to wear scarves, while you have no hair. ( They give you free make-up and scarves)  I would think if you can find one of those classes, that, one of the ladies there would shave your hair.   Just remember it does grow back, most of the time better than it was.  I was only a year without hair.  I just passed my 3 year diagnosis date and I have hair past my shoulders and I have had alot of hair cuts.  Hang in there and keep coming here for support. sherry
Posts.Title: Hair, is there a place to get it shaved free? AndreaM4567 sahalie

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2008 12:00PM sherryw wrote: Suzie  I had 3 positive lymph nodes.  I did not have the SNB, because I didn't qualify because I had a palpable lymph node under my arm (we could feel a lymph node that was about half the size of my thumb). So when I had my lumpectomy the surgeon also did the axillary node dissection at the same time.  I had a hard time with the surgery,  I had alot of pain under my arm, so much that I could not put my arm down to my side for about a month after surgery.  I still don't have feeling in my underarm after 3 years.  But I am not complaining because in am cancer free, it is a small price to pay to be able to say that.  I also agree with unlimited when she said to get the port at the same time as the node removal it will save you another surgery, and you will definitely want a port if you are getting chemo and that surgery is real easy and almost painless. I hope I haven't scared you but I wish I would have know more about the axillary node dissection surgery before I got it, so I would have know what to expect.  I hope you don't mind my honest experience about my surgery. Hang in there you will be fine sherry

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2008 12:05PM sherryw wrote: Jenn If the lump was not there last Wednesday when you noticed the discharge then I would say since it grew so quickly that it is an infection or cyst.  How old are you, and have you just recently breastfed?  Don't worry to much, It really sounds like and infection to me.  sherry
Posts.Title: Discharge and red lump jennf1023 iodine

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2008 08:27PM sherryw wrote: Mable I am so happy that your CT results were good!  I do not take the Faslodex so I am not sure if it can cause diarrhea, but I was on Herceptin for a year.  The entire time I was on the Herceptin I had chronic diarrhea from the time I started to about a month after I stopped it.  It was horrible run to the bathroom many times a day diarrhea.  My gastrointestinal doctor did both kinds of scopes trying to figure it out but found nothing, so we know it was the Herceptin,  the cure for me during that time was taking 6 Benefiber tablets a day, 2 in the morning 2 in the afternoon and 2 at night.  Trust me I didn't miss a dose.  My gastro doctor explained that many people think that fiber is just for constipation but he said that it is also used to treat diarrhea.  Not sure if you have tried this yet but if not it is well worth a try.  I hope you can find a solution. sherry
Posts.Title: CT scan results Mabledw riverinerabbit

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2008 11:42PM sherryw wrote: Patty I can't really help you with the question of having a lump under your arm without a lump in the breast.  I did find a really big lymph node under my arm about a week after I found my BC lump and it ended up it was the size of my thumb.  I ended up having 3 positive nodes out of 17.  However, on the question of a port.  When you have a port it cannot always be used for blood draws.  The nurse that is accesses the port has to have certain qualifications.  Not all nurses can do this. Chemo nurses can access it, but a nurse say in you primary doctors office probably will not be able to access it.  So if you are getting it for chemo infusion I say go for it, but if you are getting it just so it will be able to be used for occasional blood draws and IV's outside of the chemo office, I would say it would not be of much benefit.  The reason I can say this is because I had a lot of gallbladder attacks and I had pancreatitus during treatment that sent me to the hospital and it would either take forever for a qualified nurse to come and access it or they would say they couldn't use it.  When my surgeon put my port in he said to make sure I didn't let just any nurse access it because of the high risk of infection.  He told me if I had to go to the ER to not even tell them I had a port.  He only wanted the chemo nurses or the cancer floor nurses at the hospital to access it.  Also my port always worked for chemo infusions, but it would not always give a blood return so some days I ended up getting stuck in my port and also in my arm so they could get the blood they needed.  Sorry this is so long but I thought I would give you my experience. I have since had my port removed, and now when I get the occasional blood draw they use my good arm and it seems it gets harder for them to find a good vein,  I worry they will have to go to my foot or somewhere else to get blood. Hang in there sherry
